boat.construction_details: Moulded grp hull, timber decks and floors
boat.full_description: Benbow was one of the first "Castletown One-Designs" built in a mould taken from a 1905 local yawl built at Port St.Mary, IOM. About a dozen of these were made from 1999, led by the late John Qualtrough Snr. All but two of these boats were gaff-rigged to sail and race in Castletown Bay - with the original mast height limited to be able to just float in and out of Castletown harbour under the footbridge at minimum depth. Benbow was re-built from March 2021, re-launched in its present form in April 2022. The rig is an old National 18' Proctor F-section mast and boom from about 1985 - a foot-shorter than the maximum N18 mast with a slightly longer boom than standard. The 1985 sails were replaced in 2025, using "Squib" material for the mainsail - at least the colour looks traditional! Doesn't go under that bridge any more, of course...It has turned out to be a great dayboat - stiff enough for full rig up to moderate airs with 300 kgs of ballast between the 90kg centreboard and 210kgs of lead under the sole. Far too heavy and old-fashioned to exceed its hull-speed but reefed, it's superb.
boat.name: Benbow
boat.short_description: 1999 GRP version of a small work-boat built 1905.
